So the problem is about transforming that Series into a DataFrame with appropriate column names. So perhaps I should provide a solution to that specific issue. To convert the grouped result into a DataFrame with the desired structure, you can use the `.reset_index()` method on the Series. This will transform the index (Year) into a regular column and rename the count column appropriately. Here's how you can modify your code: ```python import pandas as pd # Read the CSV file into a DataFrame df = pd.read_csv('f1_data.csv') # Group by year and count occurrences of each driver, then reset index to form DataFrame driver_counts = df.groupby('Year')['Driver'].value_counts().reset_index(name='Count') # Rename columns for clarity driver_counts.columns = ['Year', 'Driver', 'Count'] print(driver_counts) ``` This will give you a DataFrame where each row represents a driver's count per year, with columns `Year`, `Driver`, and `Count`. If you only need the counts without the driver names, adjust the groupby accordingly: ```python yearly_counts = df.groupby('Year').size().reset_index(name='Count') print(yearly_counts) ``` This will create a DataFrame with just `Year` and `Count`, showing how many races occurred each year.
